case_vignette: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of a pruritic rash on the bilateral upper extremities. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. A skin biopsy of the rash shows intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes.

trial_4.summarized_conversation: A person has been experiencing an itchy rash on both upper arms for about five months. There has been no redness, swelling, or blisters associated with the rash. The rash has not spread to other areas and has remained consistently itchy. The person has not tried any treatments or seen a doctor for it until now. They have not traveled anywhere new, started any new medications, or noticed any factors that make the rash worse or better. There is no history of serious illness, surgeries that could cause the rash, or allergies. The person does not use topical creams or ointments on their skin. They do not spend a lot of time outdoors and have not noticed any patterns or triggers related to the rash. There have been no experiences of joint pain, fatigue, or fever. The person has not introduced any new foods or substances and has not noticed signs of infection or had previous skin conditions. There is no family history of autoimmune disorders, and no irritation from clothing or personal care products. The person is not experiencing unusual stress or anxiety and is not taking any medications. They have not been diagnosed with any of these conditions before.
trial_4.vignette_mcq:
The most likely diagnosis is:

Acanthosis nigricans
trial_4.multiturn_mcq:
Based on the patient's symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is:

Acanthosis nigricans
